inlineContent.text: Be the hero to change that by watching the video and providing notes! It‚Äôs super easy:

abstract.text: Discover how you can create custom iconography with the latest rendering modes in SF Symbols 3. We‚Äôll help you learn how to draw, edit, and annotate symbols, as well as explore more advanced techniques to improve the design process.

Explore the latest updates to SF Symbols, Apple‚Äôs iconography library. Designed to integrate seamlessly with San Francisco ‚Äî the system font for Apple platforms ‚Äî SF Symbols can help you create beautiful and consistent iconography for your app while supporting accessibility features like Dynamic Type and Bold Text. Discover the latest additions to the SF Symbols library, localization enhancements, and how you can more easily customize the color of a symbol to integrate it within your app‚Äôs own color palette. We‚Äôll also show you how you can design and annotate custom symbols to support Monochrome, Hierarchical, Palette, and Multicolor rendering modes.

Discover how you can incorporate SF Symbols into your SwiftUI app. We‚Äôll explore basic techniques for presenting symbols, customizing their size, and showing different variants. We‚Äôll also take you through the latest updates to symbol colorization and help you pick the right tool for your app‚Äôs needs.

Tour the latest updates to the SF Symbols app ‚Äî our interactive library for iconography. Learn how you can use the library to design accessible and inclusive apps that look incredible: We‚Äôll take you through changes to the app and symbols search, explore previewing and custom symbol management, and help you integrate symbols into your interface designs. It‚Äôs recommended you watch ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs new in SF Symbols‚Äù from WWDC21 before watching this video.

abstract.text: Learn how you can create colorized symbols with SF Symbols 3 and customize them to match the visual design of your app‚Äôs interface. We‚Äôll take you through the latest UIKit and AppKit APIs for integrating colorized symbols, as well as best practices for implementation.
Session notes shared by the community for the community.
Xcode 13, Swift 5.5, iOS 15, macOS 12 (Monterey), tvOS 15, watchOS 8.
